name: Aisha Ali
clarity_response: An app that builds a living taste profile from your experience ratings — restaurants, bars, trips — and uses friends' ratings to help you discover better things. One-tap, no reviews.
strongest_line: You've been to hundreds of places. You remember maybe twenty.
what_feels_off: Getting nitpicky here — 'taste analytics that show you patterns' in Pro still feels vague. What patterns specifically?
objections: I still need to see the interface. The copy is convincing but I'm buying the UX, not the marketing.
gut_reaction: Okay, this is really good. The specific examples still land hard and the discovery angle is even stronger now. The retroactive rating thing removes a friction point I didn't even realize I had.
unanswered_questions: What does the actual interface look like?
price_reaction: The referral incentive is smart. $12/month feels more reasonable when I can earn a free month. I'd try this.

name: Ezra Chen
clarity_response: A personal taste profile system where you rate experiences, it ranks them into a profile, and friends' network activity powers discovery. Like Beli for all experiences.
strongest_line: Not a list. Not a journal. A living, ranked record of what you've done and what you actually thought of it.
what_feels_off: The page is thorough but slightly long. I started speed-reading after the network section.
objections: 'Taste analytics' is mentioned twice without explanation. That's a potential selling point that's being wasted.
gut_reaction: The 'living taste profile' concept is sticking. The addition about Beli being 'the restaurant ranking app' helps — I already knew, but it shows attention to detail. Cold-start paragraph is smart.
price_reaction: Free tier is genuinely generous. I'd use it for a while before deciding on Pro. Fair model.

name: Daniela O'Brien
clarity_response: It turns your experience ratings into a taste profile and uses your friend network for discovery. Rate anything with one tap, find better stuff through people you trust.
strongest_line: Rate it now, or add it later — last week's dinner, last month's trip. Your profile doesn't care about timestamps.
what_feels_off: The retention section is good but could be tighter — 'designed around momentum, not effort' is a bit buzzwordy.
objections: The referral incentive is nice but assumes my friends are easy to recruit. What if they're skeptical too?
gut_reaction: I'm moving from 'interested' to 'ready to try.' The free tier including basic friend activity is the right call — I need to see the network before I pay for it.
price_reaction: The addition of basic friend activity in free is the right call. $12 for full discovery — I'd consider it.

name: Kai Franklin
clarity_response: An experience ranking app that creates a personal taste profile and surfaces recommendations from your friends' ratings. Beli for everything, not just restaurants.
strongest_line: One tap. That's it.
what_feels_off: Minor: the testimonials are better but still feel curated. Real is messy; these are clean.
objections: What platforms? iOS/Android/web? Not mentioned. Basic question left unanswered.
gut_reaction: This version tightened everything I was on the fence about. The retention section is brief but it tells me they've thought about the abandonment problem. That matters.
price_reaction: Better pricing positioning than V1. I know what I'm getting for free and what Pro adds. Transparent.

name: Diego Larsson
clarity_response: A taste profile for your real life — rate experiences, build your ranked record, and discover new things through friends' trusted recommendations.
strongest_line: Your taste deserves better than this.
what_feels_off: Nothing major. The copy is earning its length. Only the pricing section feels slightly corporate.
objections: Data portability — can I export my taste profile? Important for someone building a personal system.
gut_reaction: Strong. The only thing holding me back is wanting to see the actual interface. The copy has done its job — now I need to touch the product.
unanswered_questions: How granular is the rating system?
price_reaction: I'd start free, see value, then probably upgrade. $12/month is fair for a tool I'd use daily.

name: Isaiah Singh
clarity_response: You rate experiences, it builds a taste profile over time, and your friends' ratings power personalized discovery. Works solo too as a personal ranked history.
strongest_line: Searchable. Sortable. Yours.
what_feels_off: The 'priority in local discovery' for Pro is undefined. What does that mean in practice?
objections: How granular is the rating? 1-10? 1-5? Can I half-rate? This matters for someone who takes rating seriously.
dealbreaker_reason: Still need to see the actual UX before committing — copy alone isn't enough.
gut_reaction: The pricing section is smarter now. Invite 3 friends for free Pro is a good incentive and it aligns with how I'd naturally onboard anyway.
price_reaction: $12/month for Pro with the referral incentive — I'd earn the first month quickly. Smart.

name: Malachi Kim
clarity_response: An app that turns one-tap experience ratings into a living taste profile, with network-powered discovery from friends. Covers everything from restaurants to hikes.
strongest_line: Invite 3 friends → get your first month of Pro free.
what_feels_off: Very small nit: 'a bar you stumbled into at midnight' — same line from V1. It still feels like performing coolness.
objections: The testimonials are from early testers. I want to know how many users there are now.
gut_reaction: I like that the cold-start paragraph acknowledges solo value. I don't want an app that's useless until I recruit 10 friends.
price_reaction: The free tier being real is what builds trust. Pro is reasonable if I'm hooked.

name: Nia Adeyemi
clarity_response: A living, ranked record of your experiences that uses friend networks for discovery. One-tap rating, no writing, taste profile builds automatically.
strongest_line: A living, ranked record of what you've done and what you actually thought of it.
what_feels_off: Almost nothing. Maybe the page tries to address every objection and loses some of the punchy confidence of the opening.
objections: I'm ready to try but the free-to-Pro conversion feels like a future friction point. Will the app nag me to upgrade?
dealbreaker_reason: Still need to see the actual UX before committing — copy alone isn't enough.
gut_reaction: The discovery framing in the hero is a nice addition — 'discover what's next through the people you trust.' That's the real pitch.
unanswered_questions: Will the app nag about upgrading?
price_reaction: Good pricing. Not aggressive, not cheap. The referral path makes it feel achievable.

name: Leila Williams
clarity_response: An experience ranking system — personal taste profile plus friend-network discovery. Rate with one tap, find better things through people you trust.
strongest_line: Your taste already exists — scattered across apps, memory, and half-remembered conversations.
what_feels_off: The 'designed around momentum, not effort' line is the only part that feels like it could be from any app.
objections: Minor: what happens if I disagree with a friend's rating? Is there a way to calibrate trust?
gut_reaction: This version feels more complete. V1 was a strong pitch with gaps. This one closes most of them. I'd download the free version.
unanswered_questions: Is there a trust calibration for friends' ratings?
price_reaction: I'd pay $12/month if the product matches the copy. The free tier means I can verify first.

name: Deja Kowalski
clarity_response: It's Beli for everything: rate restaurants, bars, trips, activities with one tap. Builds your taste profile. Friends' ratings power discovery of new stuff.
strongest_line: Three months in and I still rate everything. It takes literally two seconds.
what_feels_off: Nothing feels off. This is a strong page. My remaining hesitation is about the product, not the copy.
objections: The 'patterns in what you love' for Pro — I actually want to know more about this. It could be the hook.
gut_reaction: The testimonial about three months of usage is the one that matters most to me. Retention evidence > feature lists.
price_reaction: Annual option would be nice. Monthly at $12 is fine but I'd commit for a discount.

name: Carmen Russo
clarity_response: A taste-based experience app — rate things, build your profile, discover better plans through your friend network instead of stranger reviews.
strongest_line: One tap, one number. No review. No paragraph. No photo required.
what_feels_off: The retention section is necessary but slightly breaks the confident tone of the rest — acknowledging weakness mid-pitch is risky.
objections: How does it handle categories? Rating a restaurant and a hike are different experiences.
gut_reaction: I appreciate the 'rate it now or add it later' line. My life doesn't happen on a schedule and neither should my tracking.
unanswered_questions: How does it handle mixed categories?
price_reaction: The pricing now aligns with the product's growth model. Invite friends, earn Pro. Makes sense.

name: Marcus Rivera
clarity_response: An app that creates a living taste profile from your experience ratings and helps you discover what to do next through friends' trusted activity.
strongest_line: Less mediocre. More you.
what_feels_off: Minor: 'ranked experiences across every category' in the free tier is vague. What categories?
objections: I'd want a web version for browsing my profile on desktop. Is that available?
gut_reaction: Solid. The copy respects my intelligence and my time. I'm not being sold to — I'm being informed. That's the right tone for someone like me.
price_reaction: $12/month is my ceiling for a lifestyle app. This just fits. Especially with the referral.

name: Ananya Chowdhury
clarity_response: A social taste profile app — everyone rates experiences, builds their profile, and friend networks power discovery. Like sharing your collective taste in one place.
strongest_line: Your friend who always finds the best dive bars? You'll see their top-rated spots in your neighborhood.
what_feels_off: The page is getting long. For someone clicking from an Instagram ad, there's a lot to read.
objections: The invite flow is everything. If it's clunky, the referral incentive doesn't matter. How easy is it to invite someone?
gut_reaction: The referral incentive is exactly what I needed. Invite 3 friends, get Pro free? That's how I already introduce apps — now there's a reward for it.
price_reaction: The referral incentive is perfectly designed for me. I'll invite 3 friends within a week.

name: Amir Tanaka
clarity_response: An experience ranking app where your friend group's ratings create a shared discovery layer. Personal taste profiles plus network-powered recommendations.
strongest_line: Network-powered discovery that actually feels like getting a rec from a friend. Because it is one.
what_feels_off: The retention section feels less relevant to me — I'm not worried about abandoning, I'm worried about friends abandoning.
objections: What does 'basic friend activity' in free actually include? Can I see friends' ratings or just that they rated something?
gut_reaction: Much better on the social side. Free basic friend activity means my friends can actually see what I'm rating without paying. That's the right onramp.
unanswered_questions: What exactly is 'basic friend activity' in free?
price_reaction: Free basic friend activity changes everything. My friends can see value without paying. Then they'll upgrade.

name: Keiko Yamamoto
clarity_response: You and your friends rate experiences, each building a taste profile, and the app surfaces what your trusted network rates highest. Beli for everything.
strongest_line: Now I just send them my profile.
what_feels_off: 'Priority in local discovery' for Pro — what does that mean? Feels like padding.
objections: I'd push back on $12/month if I'm doing the marketing work of inviting friends. Should be lower after referrals.
gut_reaction: This version gets the social dynamics right. The cold-start paragraph says 'it works solo first' which means I can show friends my profile before they commit.
unanswered_questions: How many friends for network to feel useful?
price_reaction: $12/month is fine for me but the free social tier is what matters for adoption. Right move.

name: Rohan Shah
clarity_response: A friend-powered experience discovery app. Rate things with one tap, build taste profiles, and find better plans through people you actually trust.
strongest_line: Invite 3 friends → get your first month of Pro free.
what_feels_off: Nothing major. The referral incentive is smart. Only concern: does '3 friends' feel too specific/gamified?
objections: How many friends need to be on it for the network to feel useful? 3? 10? 20? That affects my recruitment strategy.
gut_reaction: The friend invite incentive is smart — it aligns the business model with the product's growth mechanic. Before it felt like the pricing fought the product.
unanswered_questions: Can I share recs to non-users?
price_reaction: Much better pricing positioning. The network can grow because free users can still participate socially.

name: Omar Hayes
clarity_response: An app where you rate experiences, build your taste profile, and your friends' ratings help everyone discover better stuff. Social discovery, not algorithmic.
strongest_line: First it's your map. Then it's your map plus everyone you trust.
what_feels_off: The Beli clarification is helpful but 'the restaurant ranking app' might not mean much to people who don't rank restaurants.
objections: The referral incentive is one month. What about ongoing rewards for people who keep building the network?
gut_reaction: I'd download this now and start inviting friends. The free tier being social enough to demonstrate value is the key change.
price_reaction: I'd earn the first month of Pro immediately. After that, $12/month is fair if the network delivers.

name: Aaliyah Martinez
clarity_response: A taste profile system powered by friend networks — rate experiences, see friends' top picks, discover things through trusted signal instead of stranger reviews.
strongest_line: Not through some algorithm guessing what you might like based on 50 million strangers, but through the actual people you trust.
what_feels_off: Slight concern: the retention section might signal insecurity to confident users. 'Most apps die after a week' — am I supposed to be worried?
objections: Can I share individual recommendations to non-users? That's how I'd market this to friends.
gut_reaction: The 'before your friends join' paragraph removed my biggest concern. I can use it solo, build my profile, then share it when I invite people.
unanswered_questions: Can I share individual recs outside the app?
price_reaction: Smart to include basic friend activity in free. The old model would have killed growth.

name: Nadia Hoffman
clarity_response: It builds personal taste profiles from experience ratings and connects friends for discovery. One-tap ratings, friend-powered recommendations for everything.
strongest_line: Your friend who always finds the best dive bars? You'll see their top-rated spots in your neighborhood.
what_feels_off: Very little feels off now. The social positioning is right. Only the Pro pricing feels slightly high for a new app.
objections: What about group plans? Can friends collaborate on choosing where to go? That's my actual workflow.
gut_reaction: This version makes me want to be an evangelist for it. The referral incentive plus the social free tier gives me a pitch for my friend group.
price_reaction: I'd pay annually if there's a discount. The referral incentive gets me in the door.

name: Cedric Cruz
clarity_response: A social experience discovery app — personal taste profiles from ratings, friend network surfaces the best stuff. Works solo too, gets better with friends.
strongest_line: See what's highly rated by the people you actually trust. No strangers. No sponsored posts.
what_feels_off: The testimonials are better but I'd want numbers. How many users? Saying 'early tester' is still vague.
objections: Privacy controls — can I choose what's visible to which friends? Not all friends need to see all my ratings.
gut_reaction: The friend discovery section is still the best part. Adding the line about the friend who just moved to your city is a nice touch — that's real.
price_reaction: The pricing model now supports the product's thesis. Social grows free, power users pay. Correct.

name: Dante Cooper
clarity_response: Rate experiences with one tap, build a taste profile, discover what to do through friends' ratings. Like having your whole friend group's taste accessible.
strongest_line: Network-powered discovery that actually feels like getting a rec from a friend. Because it is one.
what_feels_off: Nothing try-hard. Nothing generic. The remaining gap is between the copy and the product — I need to try it.
objections: The page is strong but I'd want a video showing the social features in action.
gut_reaction: I'm close to all-in. The pricing model now makes sense for a social product. My only remaining question is what the invite flow looks like.
unanswered_questions: Can I see a demo of social features?
price_reaction: I'd convert to Pro within the first month. The referral gives me a free runway to evaluate.

name: Rachel Patel
clarity_response: An experience ranking app with social discovery — your ratings build your taste profile, friends' ratings build your discovery. Beli for all experiences.
strongest_line: Invite 3 friends → get your first month of Pro free.
what_feels_off: Minor: the problem section is longer now and might lose scrollers. The discovery line could come earlier.
objections: Is there a way to see friends-of-friends' recommendations, or strictly direct connections?
gut_reaction: Good improvements. The copy was already speaking my language — now the pricing matches. I'd try this and probably upgrade once friends join.
price_reaction: $12/month with ongoing referral rewards would be even better. But this is solid.

name: Megan Nakamura
clarity_response: A taste profile and discovery platform — rate experiences, build your ranked history, and find better things through your friend network's real signal.
strongest_line: This isn't a trial. It's the real product.
what_feels_off: The page tries to serve every audience. I wonder if a shorter, social-first version would convert me faster.
objections: How does the app handle different taste levels? My restaurant friends and my hiking friends are different groups.
gut_reaction: The testimonial from Jordan the recruiter feels targeted at me and I don't even mind. That IS my use case. Send profile, done.
unanswered_questions: Can I segment friends by interest?
price_reaction: Fair price. The free tier is where adoption happens, Pro is where revenue happens. They get it.

name: Tariq Oduya
clarity_response: An app that turns experience ratings into taste profiles and uses friend networks for trusted discovery. Rate once, share your taste with everyone.
strongest_line: Less mediocre. More you.
what_feels_off: Almost nothing. The referral incentive is the right mechanic. Copy is solid.
objections: I'm interested enough to download. My remaining objection is whether 3+ friends will join within the first month.
gut_reaction: Stronger than V1. The social onramp is fixed, the solo value is clear, and the referral incentive gives me a reason to evangelize.
unanswered_questions: What's the minimum viable friend group?
price_reaction: Best pricing I've seen for a social product. Free enough to spread, premium enough to sustain.

name: Tobias Kapoor
clarity_response: A one-tap experience rating app that builds a taste profile and uses friends' ratings for discovery. Designed to keep you coming back with weekly recaps and friend nudges.
strongest_line: One tap. That's it.
what_feels_off: The retention section is the right idea but 'weekly taste recaps' and 'friend activity nudges' are features, not proof. Show me data.
objections: The retention section is promising but I need to experience it, not read about it. Words won't override my pattern.
gut_reaction: The retention section is the first time any app in this category has acknowledged that I'm going to want to quit. That's... honest. And useful.
unanswered_questions: What happens on day 14 when I stop opening it?
price_reaction: I'm not paying until month 3. If I'm still using it then — and this would be unprecedented — $12/month is fine.

name: Yuki Lee
clarity_response: An experience ranking app — rate things in two seconds, it builds your taste profile, and friends' network powers discovery. Has retention features to keep you engaged.
strongest_line: Most apps like this die after a week. We know that.
what_feels_off: 'Most apps like this die after a week. We know that.' — refreshingly honest. But then the solutions are still promises, not evidence.
objections: What literally happens on day 14 when I haven't opened the app in 5 days? That's the make-or-break moment.
dealbreaker_reason: Retention section is promises, not proof. I need to experience it working.
gut_reaction: The 'rate it now or add it later' line matters more than you'd think. Half my problem is that I remember a great place the next day and by then it feels too late.
unanswered_questions: Can it detect location and prompt me?
price_reaction: The free tier is all I'll use. Maybe forever. And that's okay — the page says it's the real product.

name: Kenji Johansson
clarity_response: It's a taste profile app where you rate experiences with one tap. Friends' ratings power discovery. Says it's built around momentum, not effort.
strongest_line: Rate it now, or add it later — last week's dinner, last month's trip.
what_feels_off: The compound effect argument makes sense intellectually. Whether it works emotionally to keep me opening the app — I'm not sure.
objections: The 'profile compounds' argument is rational but my abandonment isn't rational. It's emotional — I forget, then feel guilty, then avoid.
gut_reaction: 'Most apps like this die after a week. We know that.' — okay, you have my attention. You named my exact pattern.
price_reaction: I appreciate not being pressured to pay. The generous free tier respects that I'm testing my own behavior, not just the app.

name: Jenna Okafor
clarity_response: A fast experience rating app that creates a living taste profile and uses friend networks for discovery. Emphasizes being effortless — one tap, retroactive entries allowed.
strongest_line: One tap, one number. No review. No paragraph. No photo required.
what_feels_off: I appreciate the honesty about app abandonment but the solutions listed are things every app claims. Nudges and recaps aren't new.
objections: Can the app detect when I'm at a restaurant via location and prompt me to rate? That would solve my 'remembering to open it' problem.
dealbreaker_reason: Retention section is promises, not proof. I need to experience it working.
gut_reaction: The weekly taste recap concept is interesting. That's a pull mechanism, not a push. I don't have to remember to open the app — it comes to me.
unanswered_questions: How do push notification nudges work?
price_reaction: $12/month after proving I'll stick with it — maybe. The referral incentive doesn't motivate me because I won't invite until I'm committed.

name: Theo Diaz
clarity_response: An app that builds your taste profile from quick ratings and uses friend discovery. Claims to solve the abandonment problem with nudges and compounding value.
strongest_line: This isn't an app you have to remember to open. It's one that gives you reasons to.
what_feels_off: The retention section is necessary but it's the weakest part of an otherwise strong page. It acknowledges the problem without proving the solution.
objections: The retroactive rating is great. Can I batch-rate — add 5 things from last month at once?
dealbreaker_reason: No passive tracking. Still requires me to remember to rate. My pattern will win.
gut_reaction: Better than V1 but I'm still me. I appreciate the retention section but I've heard 'we're different' before. I'd need to feel it in the app.
unanswered_questions: Is there an Apple Watch app?
price_reaction: Fair pricing. My objection was never about money — it's about whether I'll use it. Free tier solves the risk.

name: Finn Delgado
clarity_response: Rate experiences in one tap, build a taste profile, discover things through friends. Can rate retroactively. Has weekly recaps and friend activity to keep you using it.
strongest_line: Three months in and I still rate everything. It takes literally two seconds.
what_feels_off: Better than V1 but my core concern isn't addressed by copy — it's addressed by the actual product experience.
objections: How do the 'friend activity nudges' work? Push notifications? Because I turn those off for most apps.
gut_reaction: The retroactive entries are huge for me. That removes the pressure of rating in the moment, which is when I always fail.
price_reaction: I'd use free for 3 months minimum. If I'm still active, Pro is a no-brainer at $12.

name: Chloe Vasquez
clarity_response: A taste profile app — one-tap ratings, friend-network discovery, designed around momentum. Your profile gets more useful over time as you rate more.
strongest_line: The more you rate, the sharper your discovery gets — your profile compounds.
what_feels_off: The retroactive rating feature is genuinely useful. The retention section is fine. I just don't trust promises about my own behavior.
objections: The free tier is generous enough that I'd try. But 'try' and 'sustain' are very different things for me.
gut_reaction: The compound effect argument ('month three is better than day one') is smart. It gives me a reason to push through the initial effort.
price_reaction: The free tier removes my financial excuse. Now I only have to overcome my behavioral excuse. Progress.

name: Tara Ibrahim
clarity_response: An experience ranking system that builds a taste profile and connects to friends for discovery. Tries to solve retention with recaps, nudges, and compounding value.
strongest_line: Most apps like this die after a week. We know that.
what_feels_off: Nothing feels dishonest. The tone is right — honest, not hype. My skepticism is personal, not about the marketing.
objections: I'd want to see the onboarding flow. If it asks me to do too much upfront, I'll bounce immediately.
gut_reaction: I notice the retention section doesn't promise magic — it says 'momentum, not effort.' That's realistic. I trust realistic more than revolutionary.
price_reaction: Good that Pro isn't required. The free version seems genuinely useful. I'll start there.

name: Camille Bautista
clarity_response: You rate experiences quickly, it builds your taste profile, friends' ratings power discovery. Allows retroactive entries and has features meant to prevent abandonment.
strongest_line: Rate it now, or add it later.
what_feels_off: The retention section is good for someone at skepticism level 2. For me at level 4+, I need to experience it, not read about it.
objections: Is there an Apple Watch app? That would make one-tap rating actually one tap.
gut_reaction: The testimonial about three months of continuous use speaks directly to my skepticism. If someone like me stuck with it that long...
unanswered_questions: How does it handle gaps in usage?
price_reaction: Price is irrelevant until I prove retention. Free tier lets me do that. Smart.

name: Ethan Bennett
clarity_response: An app that turns fast ratings into a living taste profile with friend-powered discovery. Designed to compound — month three is better than day one.
strongest_line: Not a list. Not a journal.
what_feels_off: Minor: the page is getting long. For someone who abandons things quickly, a long landing page is ironic.
objections: The compound value argument assumes consistent use. That's the variable I can't control.
gut_reaction: Still cautiously skeptical but this version addresses my actual concerns instead of ignoring them. The cold-start and retention sections show they get it.
unanswered_questions: Can I import from other apps?
price_reaction: $12/month is fine for apps I actually use. The question is whether this joins that category.

name: Elena Stein
clarity_response: A taste-based experience tracker with friend-network discovery. One-tap rating, retroactive entries, and retention mechanics like weekly recaps.
strongest_line: One tap. That's it.
what_feels_off: Nothing feels off about the copy quality. My skepticism is about myself more than the product.
objections: I appreciate the honesty about abandonment. But the solutions are still opt-in. I need something more passive.
gut_reaction: The referral incentive doesn't do much for me — I'm not inviting friends until I've proven I'll use it. But the free tier being generous means I can try without guilt.
unanswered_questions: Is there passive tracking of any kind?
price_reaction: Not paying upfront. Free tier is the only path in for someone like me. And it's generous enough.

name: Miles Owens
clarity_response: Rate experiences in two seconds, build a taste profile, discover stuff through friends. Built to keep you engaged with weekly recaps and friend activity notifications.
strongest_line: This isn't an app you have to remember to open. It's one that gives you reasons to.
what_feels_off: The 'designed around momentum' framing is the right idea. Whether the product delivers is beyond what the page can prove.
objections: I'd want a free trial of Pro to see if friend nudges actually work for me before paying.
gut_reaction: This is the best pitch I've seen for this category. My objection isn't the copy anymore — it's my own behavior. That's progress.
price_reaction: The pricing respects that some users need time. I appreciate that.

name: Kira Petrov
clarity_response: An app that builds your taste profile from experience ratings AND helps you discover what to do next through friends' trusted recommendations. Not just tracking — discovery.
strongest_line: Choosing feels like work when you don't have a system.
what_feels_off: The forward-looking angle is way better but the discovery is still tied to friends. What if my friends aren't on the app yet?
objections: The discovery features in Pro are what I want most. Free basic friend activity might not be enough to show me the value.
gut_reaction: Now we're talking. 'Discover what's next' — that's what was missing. The copy now acknowledges that I want to DO things, not just track them.
unanswered_questions: Is there a 'what to do right now' feature?
price_reaction: Free with basic friend activity is a good start. $12/month for full discovery — I'd need to feel the value first.

name: Maya Park
clarity_response: A taste profile app that turns your ratings into a living record and uses friends' activity to help you find better plans. Both backward-looking and forward-looking.
strongest_line: Discover what's next through the people you trust.
what_feels_off: The problem section is longer now — more accurate, but also more text for someone scrolling on their phone.
objections: How does discovery work on a Saturday when I'm bored? Is there a 'show me something to do right now' feature?
gut_reaction: The new problem section nails it. 'Choosing feels like work when you don't have a system' — that's exactly why I end up on the couch.
price_reaction: The referral incentive is interesting. I'd earn a free month of Pro and then decide if it's worth $12 ongoing.

name: Mila Bergström
clarity_response: An experience discovery app powered by friend networks — rate what you do, build a taste profile, and find what to do next through people you trust.
strongest_line: You scroll through 'best of' lists, save a few posts, and end up on the couch anyway.
what_feels_off: The free tier includes 'basic friend activity' but doesn't include full discovery. The thing I want most is still paid.
objections: I might need more than friend-based discovery. What about local trending or editor picks?
gut_reaction: The discovery angle being in the hero changes the whole read. V1 felt like a journal. V2 feels like a tool that could actually change my weekends.
price_reaction: Fair pricing. The free version gives me enough to build the habit. Pro would be worth it if discovery genuinely improves my weekends.

name: Nico Brooks
clarity_response: It's a taste profile that helps you both remember what you've done and discover what to do next. Friends' ratings power the discovery. One-tap, no reviews.
strongest_line: Less mediocre. More you.
what_feels_off: Nothing feels try-hard or generic anymore. The remaining gap is between 'this sounds good' and 'I'll actually change my behavior.'
objections: $12/month is a 'think about it' price. I'd impulsively try free but deliberate about Pro.
gut_reaction: I love the friend network for discovery. If my friends are rating things nearby, that's better than scrolling Instagram saves I'll never visit.
unanswered_questions: How does an empty profile feel?
price_reaction: $12/month is 'maybe after a month' money, not 'instant yes' money. The free tier is the right entry point.

name: Soren Lam
clarity_response: An app that builds a living taste profile from your ratings and uses friend-network discovery to help you find better things to do. Like Beli for everything.
strongest_line: Network-powered discovery that actually feels like getting a rec from a friend. Because it is one.
what_feels_off: The retention section helps but it's about coming back to the app. I need help with the step before that — deciding to go somewhere.
objections: What if my friends rate things in different cities? The discovery needs to be location-aware.
dealbreaker_reason: Full discovery still paywalled. Free version doesn't solve my core problem.
gut_reaction: 'You scroll through best-of lists, save a few posts, and end up on the couch anyway.' I feel personally called out and I don't hate it.
unanswered_questions: Can I set goals or intentions?
price_reaction: I'd impulsively download for free. The referral could get me to Pro. Whether I stay is the real question.

name: Hana Reyes
clarity_response: Rate experiences, build your taste profile, and discover what's next through friends' trusted ratings. Not just logging — it helps you plan better weekends.
strongest_line: Your friend who always finds the best dive bars? You'll see their top-rated spots in your neighborhood.
what_feels_off: Slight disconnect: the copy says the app helps you discover, but the mechanism is friend ratings. I might not have many friends rating things yet.
objections: I'd want to see the discovery interface before paying. Screenshots or a demo would help.
gut_reaction: The forward-looking angle makes this feel actionable, not just reflective. I don't need another app to look backward — I need one that points forward.
unanswered_questions: What does the discovery UI look like?
price_reaction: Better than V1 pricing perception. Basic friend activity in free means the product isn't crippled.

name: Joaquin Jensen
clarity_response: A taste-based experience app that tracks what you've done and surfaces what to do next through friend networks. Personal profile plus social discovery.
strongest_line: Choosing feels like work when you don't have a system.
what_feels_off: Nothing dishonest. Just wondering if the discovery promise can deliver with a small network.
objections: The app seems designed for people who already go out. How does it help someone who needs motivation to start?
gut_reaction: The retention section is reassuring. Weekly recaps and friend nudges mean I don't have to be self-motivated. The app does some of the work.
price_reaction: I'd try free, probably use the referral to get Pro, then decide. $12/month is fair if it delivers.

name: Zoe Fernandez
clarity_response: An app where your experience ratings build a taste profile, and friends' ratings help you discover what to do. Both a record and a discovery system.
strongest_line: You keep ending up at the same three places.
what_feels_off: The 'choosing feels like work when you don't have a system' line is the most accurate thing I've read about my problem. No notes on that.
objections: Can I set goals or intentions? Like 'try 3 new restaurants this month'? That would help with follow-through.
gut_reaction: Much stronger. The discovery framing makes the network section feel relevant to me, not just to social butterflies who already go out a lot.
price_reaction: Annual pricing with a discount would convert me faster. Monthly feels like I'm being metered.

name: Priya Chang
clarity_response: Experience ranking meets social discovery — rate things, build your taste profile, find better plans through friends instead of scrolling 'best of' lists.
strongest_line: Discover what's next through the people you trust.
what_feels_off: Minor: 'taste analytics that show you patterns' — cool concept but feels like it's for power users, not for someone still building the habit.
objections: The referral incentive is nice but I'd want to use it a few weeks before inviting friends.
dealbreaker_reason: Full discovery still paywalled. Free version doesn't solve my core problem.
gut_reaction: This version makes me want to download it. Not sure I'd pay $12/month yet, but the free version with basic friend activity is enough to start.
unanswered_questions: Can I save future plans, not just past?
price_reaction: The free tier is good enough that I'd actually try it. Pro is aspirational — 'the better version of me would pay for this.'

name: Mateo Griffin
clarity_response: A living taste profile app — rate experiences, see patterns in what you love, and discover new things through your friend network's real signal.
strongest_line: Your taste deserves better than this.
what_feels_off: The forward-looking reframe works. My only lingering doubt is whether I'd actually follow through or just save the app and forget.
objections: How empty does a new profile feel? If day one is staring at a blank screen, I won't come back.
gut_reaction: The specific addition about choosing being hard when you don't have a system — that's exactly right. The taste profile IS the system. I get it now.
unanswered_questions: How does friend discovery display — feed, map?
price_reaction: $12/month is competing with Netflix, Spotify, etc. It needs to earn that slot. The free tier lets me evaluate.

name: Ravi Okonkwo
clarity_response: An app that creates a personal taste profile and uses friend-powered discovery to help you find things to do. Not just memory — it's forward-looking too.
strongest_line: See what's highly rated by the people you actually trust.
what_feels_off: Nothing major feels off. The copy is honest and specific. My challenge is internal, not about the messaging.
objections: The free version might not give me enough to stay engaged. But $12/month is a commitment.
gut_reaction: I can finally see how this would change a Saturday. See friends' top-rated spots, pick one, go. That's simpler than scrolling for an hour.
price_reaction: Fair. The referral is a smart nudge. I'd probably end up on Pro through that path.

name: Jordan Nguyen
clarity_response: Rates and ranks your experiences into a taste profile, then uses friend networks to help you discover better plans. Designed to get you off the couch.
strongest_line: Less mediocre. More you.
what_feels_off: The problem section might be doing too much now — the original two paragraphs were tighter. The new addition is good but the section is long.
objections: I'm more interested than before but still not sure this changes my weekend behavior vs just documenting it.
gut_reaction: Way better. V1 told me to record my life. V2 tells me to upgrade it. Big difference.
price_reaction: Good pricing structure. Free to try, paid for power. I just need the free experience to be good enough to hook me.

name: Samir Novak
clarity_response: An app that builds a taste profile from your experience ratings and uses friend networks for discovery. Works solo from day one as a personal ranked map, gets better with friends.
strongest_line: First it's your map. Then it's your map plus everyone you trust.
what_feels_off: The cold-start paragraph is great but 'as your network grows' is vague. How many people do I need for discovery to be useful?
objections: How many active users are in my city? The network promise is only as good as the network size.
gut_reaction: The cold-start paragraph is exactly what I needed. 'First it's your map. Then it's your map plus everyone you trust.' Perfect — I start solo, network grows.
unanswered_questions: How many active users in my city?
price_reaction: Free for my personal taste map, Pro for network discovery. Makes sense. I'd start free and upgrade when my network forms.

name: Declan Watanabe
clarity_response: A taste-based experience ranking app with friend-powered discovery. Start with your own taste map, then layer in friends' ratings as your network grows. Beli for everything.
strongest_line: My friends' ratings have been better than any 'best of' list.
what_feels_off: Very little. The solo-first pitch is exactly right. Only question: does 'local discovery' in Pro mean beyond friends?
objections: Is there community discovery beyond friends? Local trending, popular spots, power user lists?
dealbreaker_reason: Need community discovery, not just friend discovery. No friends here yet.
gut_reaction: This version acknowledges my situation directly. The personal taste map framing makes the solo experience feel valuable, not like a crippled version.
price_reaction: $12/month is reasonable for quality local discovery. The referral incentive means I'd invite meetup friends.

name: Iris Torres
clarity_response: An experience ranking app — rate everything, build your taste profile, and discover through friends. Works solo at first as a personal map, scales with your network.
strongest_line: That friend who just moved to your city and has been exploring nonstop? Their discoveries become yours.
what_feels_off: Nothing feels off. The copy now speaks to my situation. The 'first it's your map' line is perfect.
objections: Can I follow local tastemakers or food bloggers on the platform? That would bootstrap my discovery.
gut_reaction: The friend who just moved to your city and has been exploring nonstop — that's ME. Someone on this team understands my use case.
price_reaction: The free tier with basic friend activity is the right level for day one. I'd upgrade once I have local friends on it.

name: Reese Mensah
clarity_response: A living taste profile that ranks your experiences and uses friend networks for discovery. Useful alone from day one — your personal taste map of a new city.
strongest_line: Network-powered discovery that actually feels like getting a rec from a friend. Because it is one.
what_feels_off: Minor: the page doesn't mention location-aware features. Does the app know where I am and suggest nearby?
objections: Does the app know my location and surface nearby recommendations? That's critical for exploring.
gut_reaction: Strong. The cold-start concern is addressed, the discovery is clearer, and the referral incentive means I'd invite the people I meet at meetups.
price_reaction: Fair pricing. The free tier gives me enough to start mapping my new city. Pro is the natural upgrade path.

name: Leo Abadi
clarity_response: An app that turns experience ratings into a taste profile and powers discovery through friend networks. Solo value as a ranked map, social value as friends join.
strongest_line: A living, ranked record of what you've done and what you actually thought of it.
what_feels_off: The cold-start is addressed but community discovery (beyond friends) isn't mentioned. I'd want to see local popular spots too.
objections: The referral incentive makes sense — I'd invite people I meet at meetups. But 3 might take a few weeks.
gut_reaction: I'd sign up today. The solo taste map plus growing network is the right pitch. I don't need all my friends on day one.
price_reaction: I'd use the referral immediately. Meeting 3 new people a week at events — inviting them is easy.

name: Simone Baptiste
clarity_response: Rate experiences one tap, build a taste profile. Discovery comes from friends' ratings. Starts as your personal ranked map and grows into network-powered discovery.
strongest_line: First it's your map. Then it's your map plus everyone you trust.
what_feels_off: Almost nothing. The Beli clarification helps, the cold-start paragraph helps, the referral incentive helps. Strong page.
objections: Is there a map view of my rated experiences? That's how I'd want to see my taste profile of a new city.
gut_reaction: Love the Beli clarification. I use Beli for restaurants and now I get exactly what this is. The expansion to everything is the obvious next step.
price_reaction: $12/month is in my budget. The question is timing — I'd want free for a month before upgrading.

name: Jasmine Anderson
clarity_response: A taste profile and discovery app — rate everything, build your ranked record. Works alone as your personal map, then friends' ratings make discovery even better.
strongest_line: Invite 3 friends → get your first month of Pro free.
what_feels_off: Slight concern: 'priority in local discovery' for Pro — does that imply free users get limited local results?
objections: Can I filter discovery by neighborhood? That's how I explore — area by area.
gut_reaction: The retention mechanics — weekly recaps, friend nudges — would be great for someone in my situation. I'm discovering so much that I need help remembering it all.
unanswered_questions: How to find community without knowing users?
price_reaction: Good model. Start solo, grow social, upgrade when the network justifies it. I'd follow that path.

name: Ingrid Gupta
clarity_response: An experience ranking app with friend discovery. Builds your personal taste profile from day one, adds network recommendations as friends join. Beli for all experiences.
strongest_line: Your personal taste profile is valuable on its own — a searchable, ranked record.
what_feels_off: The page is longer but earns its length. Nothing feels padded. Only want: a mention of map or location features.
objections: How does it handle someone who's rating 10+ new places a week? Is it designed for high-volume exploration?
gut_reaction: This version removed my main objection. The personal map from day one is enough to start. Network discovery is the bonus that keeps me engaged as I meet people.
price_reaction: The referral incentive is perfectly designed for my situation. I'm already meeting new people constantly.

name: Caleb Santos
clarity_response: An app that creates a living taste profile from your ratings. Start solo with your own ranked map, then discover through friends as your network grows.
strongest_line: Network-powered discovery that actually feels like getting a rec from a friend. Because it is one.
what_feels_off: Nothing feels off. My remaining objection is about network size in my specific city, which the page can't fully address.
objections: What about visiting different cities? Can I build a taste profile across multiple locations?
gut_reaction: Perfect for where I am in life. Building a taste map of my new city is exactly the frame I needed. Not journaling — mapping.
price_reaction: Annual pricing would commit me faster. Monthly at $12 is fine but feels tentative.

name: Noah Malik
clarity_response: A personal taste profile for your experiences — restaurants, bars, hikes — with friend-powered discovery layered on top. Useful solo, better with friends.
strongest_line: First it's your map. Then it's your map plus everyone you trust.
what_feels_off: Very minor: the retention section is less relevant for someone in exploration mode — I'm not at risk of abandoning because I'm still in the honeymoon phase.
objections: The solo taste map is enough to get me started. But I'd want to see community features before paying for Pro.
gut_reaction: The testimonial about Chicago still hits but now the cold-start paragraph means I'm not worried about not having local friends yet.
price_reaction: $12/month for reliable local discovery is a bargain compared to wasting money on random restaurants.

name: Andre Morales
clarity_response: An experience ranking system that builds your personal taste map and uses friend networks for discovery. Works alone first, gets richer as your network grows.
strongest_line: Think Beli — the restaurant ranking app — but for everything.
what_feels_off: Nothing. This page would convert me. The only question is whether the product delivers.
objections: How do I discover the app's community in my city without already knowing users?
dealbreaker_reason: Need community discovery, not just friend discovery. No friends here yet.
gut_reaction: I'd try Pro with the referral incentive. I'm meeting new people every week at meetups — inviting 3 to the app is easy.
price_reaction: The free tier is generous enough to be genuinely useful solo. Pro is the clear upgrade once friends join.

name: Olivia Dubois
clarity_response: Builds a living taste profile from your experience ratings. Solo as a personal ranked map, social as friends join. One tap, friend-powered discovery, Beli for everything.
strongest_line: Less mediocre. More you.
what_feels_off: The cold-start paragraph is the single most important addition for someone in my situation. Well done.
objections: Minor: does the app work in non-US cities? I might relocate internationally.
gut_reaction: Sold. The solo-first, network-second pitch is the right architecture for someone building from scratch.
price_reaction: Fair price. I'd earn the referral quickly and use the free month to decide on ongoing.
